intro: Rhexia mariana var. ventricosa, commonly known as the swamp pink, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in the eastern United States. It is characterized by its showy, pinkish-red flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils and is often found in bogs, marshes, and along the edges of ponds. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are often hairy and somewhat succulent. This variety is part of the Geraniaceae family and is noted for its ecological importance in supporting pollinators and maintaining wetland biodiversity.
